review.title: Commonsense reasoning, commonsense knowledge, and the SP theory of intelligence
review.abstract: This paper describes how the "SP theory of intelligence", outlined in an Appendix, may throw light on aspects of commonsense reasoning (CSR) and commonsense knowledge (CSK) (together shortened to CSRK), as discussed in another paper by Ernest Davis and Gary Marcus (DM). The SP system has the generality needed for CSRK: Turing equivalence; the generality of information compression as the foundation for the SP system both in the representation of knowledge and in concepts of prediction and probability; the versatility of the SP system in the representation of knowledge and in aspects of intelligence including forms of reasoning; and the potential of the system for the seamless integration of diverse forms of knowledge and diverse aspects of intelligence. Several examples discussed by DM, and how they may be processed in the SP system, are discussed. Also discussed are current successes in CSR (taxonomic reasoning, temporal reasoning, action and change, and qualitative reasoning), how the SP system may promote seamless integration across these areas, and how insights gained from the SP programme of research may yield some potentially useful new ways of approaching these topics. The paper considers how the SP system may help overcome several challenges in the automation of CSR described by DM, and how it meets several of the objectives for research in CSRK that they have described.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: So say Ernest Davis and Gary Marcus [5, p. 92], who illustrate the point with questions that are easy for humans to answer but can be difficult for artificial systems, such as "Who is taller, Prince William or his son?" and "Can you make a salad from a polyester shirt?" (ibid.) Questions like these can be a way forward for the SP theory of intelligence and its translation into the SP computer model outlined in Appendix A.

sections.heading: 2 Why the SP system may provide a foundation
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that these two are very complex matters, and that this is a very complex and complex matter.

sections.heading: 3 Versatility in the representation of knowledge
sections.text: The quest for simplification and integration of observations and concepts in AI and related fields has led to the creation of a system that combines relative simplicity in its organization with versatility in the representation of different forms of knowledge and versatility in different aspects of intelligence, as outlined in the following sections. As mentioned in Appendix A. It is provided that all kinds of knowledge in the SP system are represented with SP patterns, which means arrays of atomic symbols in one or two dimensions. Despite their simplicity, SP patterns have been shown to be effective within the multidimensional alignment framework when it comes to representing multiple forms of knowledge, each of which can serve in the CSC, including: the syntax of natural language; class hierarchies, class heterarchies (i.e. class hierarchies with cross-division); partial whole hierarchies; discrimination networks and trees; entity relationship structures; relational knowledge; rules for the use in the argumentation; in one pattern; in one dimension; or in two dimensions; and [in detail] three; and in two dimensions.

sections.heading: 4 Versatility in aspects of intelligence
sections.text: Despite the basic simplicity of the SP system, it shows strengths and potential in several aspects of intelligence, including: unattended learning; natural language processing; blurred pattern recognition; multi-level recognition; best-match and semantic forms of information gathering; different ways of thinking (more in Section 5, below); planning and problem solving ([14, chapters 5 to 9], [15, section 10]).

sections.heading: 4.2 Inheritance of attributes
sections.text: As already indicated, recognition by multiple alignment, with class relations and sub-relationships, provides a means of reaching a kind of conclusion that is bread and butter in everyday reasoning and thinking. This kind of conclusion, which is called "inheritance of attributes" in object-oriented programming, 4 and refers to "prediction by partial alignment" in information compression, 5, means predicting the invisible parts of a pattern that has been detected, or a number of such patterns. With recognition by multiple alignment, this can happen at all levels of multiple alignment, with the exception of column 0. Thus, for example, in the multiple alignment in Figure 1, we can conclude that the plant has Ranunculus acris chalices that are not reflected, and leaves that are composed and cut palmat (the "species plane" in column 1) that the plant is nourished by photosynthesis.

sections.heading: 5 Versatility in reasoning
sections.text: Although reasoning is an aspect of intelligence (Section 4), due to the versatility of the SP system in this area and because it is a key component of CSR, the strengths and potentials of the SP system include ([14, Chapter 7], [15, Section 10]): "deductive" thinking in one step; reasoning chains; deductive thinking; arguing with probabilistic networks and trees; arguing with "rules"; non-monotonous thinking and arguing with default values; Bayesian thinking with "clearing the way" (as discussed by Judea Pearl in [9, Sections 1.2.2 and 2.2.4]); causal thinking; and arguing that is not supported by evidence. As we have seen in Section 4.2 or Section 4.2, the SP system also supports conclusions by inheriting attributes. It seems that there is also potential for spatial thinking [17, Section IV-F. 1] and for what would be appropriate in Section 4.2 or Section 4.2.

sections.heading: 5.1 Nonmonotonic reasoning and reasoning with default
sections.text: A popular example of the multiple alignment in Figure 2 is that when we are told that "Tweety" is a bird, we would normally infer the strength of the standard assumption that most birds can fly, that it is likely that Tweety can fly. But, if we are later told that Tweety is a penguin, we will rethink our thinking and almost certainly come to the conclusion that Tweety cannot fly. This is contrary to the classical logic in which later evidence should not change an earlier conclusion - but it is completely consistent with everyday thinking and CSR. With an appropriate memory of old patterns, and the new pattern "Tweety" (which can be interpreted as "Tweety is a bird"), the best of the multiple alignments generated by the SP computer model is that shown in Figure 2 ([15, Section 10.1], Section 7.7] that the new pattern is "corresponding to Tweety."

sections.heading: 5.2 Spatial reasoning
sections.text: As mentioned in Appendix A, it is provided that knowledge in the SP system can be represented with two-dimensional patterns and 1D patterns, and that the SP computer model is generalized to work with 2D patterns, which should facilitate, among other things, the learning of 3D structures and the application of such structures in spatial thinking. In terms of learning 3D structures, the SP system can create a 3D model of an object or another structure by assembling partially overlapping images of the structure taken from different angles, as schematically illustrated in Figure 4. The process of recognizing partial similarities between images would be done by searching for good complete and partial similarities between patterns, a process that is central to the functioning of the SP system [16, Sections 6.1 and 6.2]. The creation of a 3D digital model of an object of an object from overlapping images is already performed by commercially available systems, using a quadrilateral form, and Google view to create a quadrilateral image in the form of a quadrilateral application.

sections.heading: 7 Father and son, and other examples
sections.text: This and the following main sections discuss aspects of the CSRC in light of what was said about the SP system earlier in this paper and in Appendix A. The discussion focuses mainly on what Davis and Marcus (DM) have said about CSRK in, and uses several of their headlines. In their introduction to CSRK, DM give some examples of natural language and everyday situations that are easy for people to understand, but difficult for AI systems. • Who is taller, Prince William or his baby son Prince George? • DM say if you hold a six foot tall person in his arms, and you are told that they are father and son who do not need to ask. sections.heading: 8 Commonsense in intelligent tasks
sections.text: The Tbis section covers a selection of topics that DM considers under the heading above.

sections.heading: 8.1 The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a per-
sections.text: As DM (p. 93) notes, the subtlety of natural language can be seen in two examples set out by Terry Winograd in [12, p. 33]: • The councillors refused permission to the demonstrators because they feared violence. [14] The councillors refused permission to the demonstrators because they were in favour of the revolution. Of course, people assume that in the first sentence "they" means the councillors, while in the second sentence "they" means the demonstrators, but these two conclusions can be problematic for the AI systems. As with the examples in Section 7, a complete interpretation of such sentences is outside the framework of the SP computer model in its present form. However, as before, the key to interpreting these sentences seems to be the inheritance of attributes as discussed in Sections 7 and 4.1. It is well known that councillors as a class usually want to maintain peace in their city, while a subgroup of the above-mentioned "supporters" inherit knowledge of the importance of the revolution. sections.heading: 8.2.2 ‘Seeing’ things that are not objectively present in an image
sections.text: The SP computer model describes some types of situations in which people "see" things that are not objectively present in an image: • Just as we can conclude in the detection example discussed in Section 4.1 that the unknown plant has features that are not contained in the New Information supplied to the SP computer model (cups that are not reflected, leaves that are composed and cut by hand, that the plant nourishes itself through photosynthesis and that it is poisonous), we can derive objects that are not contained in an image and use them for an object that is also not visible. • David Marr [7] describes two examples in which people "see" things that are not objectively present in an image: the sides of a triangle that can be seen in Kanizsa's triangle, although it is mostly empty space (ibid., Figure 2-6); and the line in a photo of a plant in which another leaf overlaps, we can see.

sections.heading: 8.3 Robotic manipulation
sections.text: Although the SP concepts, as described in [17], seem to be highly relevant to the development of robot intelligence, no attempt has been made so far to address problems that DM describes as follows: 16 "When a cat runs in front of a housecleaning robot, the robot should not run it over, nor clean it up, or put it on a shelf. These things seem obvious, but ensuring that a robot avoids mistakes of this kind is a major challenge." [5, p. 94] However, it seems likely that the strengths and potential of the SP system in various forms of argumentation (Section 5, [17, Section IV-F]) will help it avoid the errors outlined by DM.

sections.heading: 9 Successes in automated commonsense reason-
sections.text: ingThis section looks at four areas where, as described by DM, there has been success with other approaches and compares them with what can be done with the SP system.

sections.heading: 9.1 Taxonomic reasoning
sections.text: As we have seen in Section 4.1, taxonomic relationships can be expressed with SP patterns, with pattern recognition at multiple levels of abstraction.

sections.heading: 9.1.1 Basic relations
sections.text: With regard to the three basic taxonomic relationships described by DM: • An individual is a case of a category. This can be seen by the fact that the unknown plant in the example shown in Figure 1 can be identified as an example of the species Meadow Buttercup, a member of the genus Ranunculus, a member of the family Ranunculaceae, etc. • One category is a subset of another. In the SP system, this type of relationship is expressed by pairs of symbols such as "< genus >... < / genus >," which in the figure indicate the connection between the pattern describing the term "genus" (column 6 in the figure) and the pattern describing the term "species" (column 1). • Two categories are separated from each other. In the SP system, this type of relationship can be implicit in a collection of SP patterns.

sections.heading: 9.1.2 Categories and properties
sections.text: In this context, an important feature of the SP system is that there is no distinction between categories and properties (also known as classes and attributes), and similarly there is no distinction between "classes" and "objects," a distinction that plays a prominent role in object-oriented programming. In the SP system, all such concepts are modeled with "patterns" and "symbols," although concepts such as "category" and "property" can be used informally where appropriate. There are three main advantages in eliminating these distinctions: • It facilitates the seamless integration of class relations with sub-relationships, as illustrated in Figure 1.

sections.heading: 9.1.3 Forms of inference
sections.text: With regard to the taxonomic forms of conclusion discussed by DM: • transitivity. "Since lassie is an instance of dog and dog, it follows that lassie is an instance of mammals." [5, p. 95] In the SP system, relationships like this can be implicit in a series of patterns that describe different categories of animals; they would not be explicitly encrypted. • standard inheritance. "One variant of [inheritance] is standard inheritance; a category can be marked with a characteristic but not universal property, and a subcategory or instance will inherit ownership unless it is explicitly repealed." (ibid.) As in Section 5.1, the SP system can model reasoning with standard assumptions. 7When I have been used in the software industry and am working on developing a "support environment" for software developers, it becomes clear that it goes as far as integrating classes or sub-products with software products and sub-products.

sections.heading: 9.2 Temporal reasoning
sections.text: DM writes: "For example, if one knows that Mozart was born earlier and died younger than Beethoven, one can conclude that Mozart died earlier than Beethoven.... The integration of such considerations into specific applications, such as the interpretation of natural language, was... problematic.... Many important temporal relationships are not explicitly stated in texts, they are derived, and the process of concluding them can be difficult." [5, p. 96] No attempt has been made to apply the SP system to temporal considerations, so the remarks here are tentative. As we have seen in Section 5.2, the SP system has potential for creating 3D digital models of objects and environments and for spatial considerations with such models. The suggestion here, partly motivated by what people seem to be doing in the argument about temporal relations, is that such an argument is made in a manner similar to the problem or the same problem as spatial reasoning, by directly manipulating the temporal description of objects.

sections.heading: 9.3 Action, change, and qualitative reasoning
sections.text: DM describe two other areas of success of automated common sense reasoning [5, pp. 96-97]: • Action and Change. Modeling of subsequent processes related to actions, events, and changes with possibly oversimplified assumptions such as... "an event occurs at a time, and the rational person only needs to consider the state of the world at the beginning and end of the event..." and "Any change in the world is the result of an event." • Qualitative reasoning. Modeling forms of qualitative reasoning such as how the price of a product affects the number of goods sold and how a rise in the temperature of a gas in a closed container leads to an increase in pressure. As with time reasoning, no attempt has been made to apply the SP system to these areas, so comments on them are tentative - and they are reserved for the following subsection.

sections.heading: 9.4 Discussion
sections.text: As DM says, there have been some successes in the four areas discussed above (Section 9), but there is a major shortcoming that will be outlined in the next subsection, and findings from the SP research program suggest some potentially useful new ways to approach these issues that will be discussed in the subsection below. However, the successes described by DM may also include some useful statements about the SP system and overcoming weaknesses in the system.8See "Cuisenaire Rods," Wikipedia, bit.ly / 2bOEQ6N, retrieved 2016-09-05.20

sections.heading: 9.4.1 Compatibility and integration
sections.text: What seems to be the biggest shortcoming of the four areas of success in CSRC described by DM is that they appear to have been developed entirely independently of each other or from other aspects of intelligence. This is the kind of fragmentation in AI that Pamela McCorduck so clearly criticized: "The goals once articulated with intellectual vigor by AI pioneers seemed unattainable." [8, p. 417] And fragmentation is at odds with the central goal of SP research to promote simplification and integration of observations and concepts across a broad canon (Appendix A). The penalty for developing these four areas independently is that there is little or no integration between them, and they seem to have little or nothing to do with each other. Since they all deal with aspects of CSRC, it is rather disappointing that there is no benefit to intelligence.

sections.heading: 9.4.2 Unsupervised learning as a guide to CSRK
sections.text: Given the current state of development of the SP system, as expressed in the SP computer model, a potentially useful method for developing ideas in the areas of taxonomic thinking, time thinking, action and change, and qualitative thinking, and in other aspects of AI is something like this: 1. Develop unattended learning in the SP system to solve residual problems as outlined in [15, Section 3.3]. 9Use suitable new patterns to examine the best grammars (sets of old patterns) created by unattended learning in the computer model, and9The main problem at the moment is that the SP computer model does not learn intermediate levels of abstraction - but it seems that this problem is solvable. It would also be useful to generalize the computer model to work with patterns in two dimensions. 21Assess how their strengths and weaknesses in the representations of knowledge and in relation to inferential processes in various areas of the CSR.3. sections.heading: 10.3.2 Seamless integration of CSR
sections.text: As described in Section 6 and elsewhere in this paper, the use of a very simple format to represent all types of knowledge and a relatively simple framework - multiple alignment - for the processing of knowledge should facilitate the seamless integration of different types of knowledge and different aspects of intelligence. These remarks apply equally to the different forms of thinking within the actual or potential capabilities of the SP system (Sections 5 and 10.3.1). As mentioned in Section 6, common experience suggests that the seamless integration of different types of knowledge and different forms of thinking are prerequisites for the kind of healthy thinking that we constantly apply in many different situations.

sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most people who are able are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they do not want.

sections.heading: 10.5 Discerning the proper level of abstraction
sections.text: ... "when formulating knowledge, it is often difficult to discern the right level of abstraction.... Consider the example of putting a pin into a carrot and the task of thinking that while this action can create a hole in the carrot, it cannot create a hole in the pin.... The question is how broadly such rules should be formulated." [5, pp. 98-99] In short, the supposed "SP" answer to the "right level of abstraction" and "how broadly... rules should be formulated" are compression information. Consistent with the argument in Section 9.4 - that we should not try to determine knowledge structures by analysis, but should orient ourselves toward what emerges from a well constructed ICMA-based learning system - we should see what levels of abstraction result from learning about ICMA.

sections.heading: 10.6 Methodological and sociological obstacles
sections.text: "One final reason for the slow progress in the automation of common sense is both methodologically and sociologically. Pieces of sound knowledge (e.g. specific facts) are relatively easy to acquire, but often of little use because of the long-tail phenomenon discussed earlier, so it may not be particularly valuable to be able to argue a little common sense." [5, p. 99] The main points in this subsection are puzzling. It is not clear why piecemeal sound knowledge should be of little use, or why the long-tail phenomenon is relevant. A young child is likely to quickly learn that burning is painful, but eating is usually nice, and such knowledge is likely to prove useful, even though it is specific facts, and they are associated with common situations that do not fall into the "long-tail" category.

metadata.abstractText: This paper describes how the SP theory of intelligence, outlined in an Appendix, may throw light on aspects of commonsense reasoning (CSR) and commonsense knowledge (CSK) (together shortened to CSRK), as discussed in another paper by Ernest Davis and Gary Marcus (DM). The SP system has the generality needed for CSRK: Turing equivalence; the generality of information compression as the foundation for the SP system both in the representation of knowledge and in concepts of prediction and probability; the versatility of the SP system in the representation of knowledge and in aspects of intelligence including forms of reasoning; and the potential of the system for the seamless integration of diverse forms of knowledge and diverse aspects of intelligence. Several examples discussed by DM, and how they may be processed in the SP system, are discussed. Also discussed are current successes in CSR (taxonomic reasoning, temporal reasoning, action and change, and qualitative reasoning), how the SP system may promote seamless integration across these areas, and how insights gained from the SP programme of research may yield some potentially useful new ways of approaching these topics. The paper considers how the SP system may help overcome several challenges in the automation of CSR described by DM, and how it meets several of the objectives for research in CSRK that they have described.
